1.1.1.author: Rick Huizinga <rickhuizinga@gmail.com>
1.1.1.message: Fixed rare issue (based on complicated DOM tree where google-map is created/destroyed by conditional ng-include statement) where watching directive center/zoom attributes was not updating map.  Case was newValue === oldValue but oldValue did not equal current settings in Google Maps object.  Removed test for newValue === oldValue but still avoids unnecessary Google Map object changes during watch initialization because Google Maps object is only updated if different from newValue

1.1.0.author: Rick Huizinga <rickhuizinga@gmail.com>
1.1.0.message: Improved performance of static attribute: the watcher was being called on initialization (even for a shallow watch) resulting in it reconverting the entire path array due to tiny differences in the floating point numbers between it and the previously set Google Maps array.  'static' implies no watch (i.e. the array does not change).  ALSO the GeoJSON path cannot be watched by  because the path points are located two-levels deep in the object.  performs a shallow watch on the first level only so GeoJSON paths now use .

1.1.0.author: Rick Huizinga <rickhuizinga@gmail.com>
1.1.0.message: Fixed problem where static attribute was ignored when setting up the watch on the path array. Fixed problem where watch was not being called until the scope was destroyed.

1.1.0.author: Rick Huizinga <rickhuizinga@gmail.com>
1.1.0.message: Added support for GeoJSON objects for path parameter/attribute in polygon & polyline directives.  This is in addition to the existing latitude/longitude object arrays.  Also added example page using GeoJSON coordinates and example page with polygons containing a huge number of points to demonstrate the use of the new static parameter/attribute for the polygon and polyline directives

1.1.0.author: Rick Huizinga <rickhuizinga@gmail.com>
1.1.0.message: Added static attribute to polygon directive. Dramatically improves performance of polygons especially those containing thousands of points. Setting the static attribute to true implies that both the polygon's points are static (do not change) and that the polygon is for display only (i.e. is not editable).  As a result setting static to true overrides the editable attribute.  The performance benefit comes from the fact that the directive does not need to watch for edits from Google Maps and does not need to perform deep watch on every polygon co-ordinate during every Angular digest cycle. (Although a watch is still performed on the path attribute for changes by reference so that the entire polygon can still be changed.)  On a map with multiple polygons with a total of 25000+ coordinates the browser would simply fail without the static atttribute with the static attribute set to true the polygons are displayed almost instantly.

1.0.6.author: Nick McCready <nmccready@gmail.com>
1.0.6.message: fix issue #193 - window now watches a marker's directive scope now if it exists for   coords. This prevents creating extra windows when one already exists. This also fixes the click example in example.html and if the window is already open it will now follow the marker around the map. controller in Marker now returns getMarkerScope instead of getMarker gMarker is in the scope

1.0.0.author: Nick McCready <nmccready@gmail.com>
1.0.0.message: - added dragging attribute to the google-map directive - this is important as to not rehash the functionality of "is dragging"   that is already done in the directive controller - this is more important that knowing if the center has changed as you   only want to dynamically load new markers when dragging has stopped.

1.0.0.author: Ryan Katkov <ryan@life360.com>
1.0.0.message: Add icon binding for custom marker icons Icon is Array with icon = {icon:'/url/img.png'} Options can be passed into the array see: https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/reference#Icon

1.0.0.author: Adrian Hara <info@adrianhara.com>
1.0.0.message: Added possibility to specify "templateUrl" and "templateParameter" for a window directive. Doing so permits loading the InfoWindow content from an external template. The template is also compiled so it can be "stand-alone" (having a controller etc)
